study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if frequent moderate exacerbations accelerate clinical and functional decline in ex-smoking COPD patients, including effects on walking performance (6-minute walking test).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in FEV1 decline or other functional outcomes (including 6-minute walking test) between frequent and infrequent exacerbators, suggesting frequent moderate exacerbations do not accelerate decline in ex-smoking COPD patients.
population_specificity: Ex-smoking COPD patients (n=100)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a home aerobic exercise program (walking) in improving cardiovascular performance and reducing adverse events in ICD recipients.
results_summary: The study found that prescribed home walking significantly improved peak oxygen consumption at 8 and 24 weeks compared to usual care, with no significant differences in ICD shocks, hospitalizations, or deaths between groups.
population_specificity: 160 patients (124 men, 36 women) with implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs) for primary or secondary prevention.
effective_dosage: 1 hour/day, 5 days/week at 60-80% of heart rate reserve for 8 weeks, followed by 150 minutes/week for 16 weeks.
study_duration: 24 weeks (8 weeks of training, 16 weeks of maintenance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ambulation training with surface peroneal nerve stimulation versus usual care on gait parameters in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: Both treatment groups showed improvements in cadence, stride length, walking speed, and peak hip and ankle power, but there were no significant differences between the groups. Peak ankle dorsiflexion in swing worsened in both groups, though the clinical significance is unclear.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors (>12 weeks poststroke) with unilateral hemiparesis.
study_duration: 12 weeks of treatment, with a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether patient-specific instrumentation (PSI) improved gait, implant positioning, and patient-reported outcomes compared to conventional instrumentation in unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA) patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in gait parameters, implant alignment, or functional outcomes between PSI and conventional UKA techniques at 3 months and 1 year post-surgery. PSI did not demonstrate a clear advantage over conventional methods.
population_specificity: 60 patients (mean age 63 ± 4 years, mean BMI 28 ± 3 kg/m²) undergoing UKA.
study_duration: Evaluated at 3 months and 1 year post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify clinical, laboratory, and imaging features that distinguish gout from non-gout conditions.
results_summary: The study identified ten key features, including difficulty walking (multivariate OR 7.34), that accurately distinguish gout from non-gout. Ultrasound findings and serum urate levels added significant discriminating value.
population_specificity: Consecutive rheumatology clinic patients with ≥1 swollen joint or subcutaneous tophus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of locomotor training intensity on walking outcomes in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: High-intensity training (70%-80% of heart rate reserve) led to greater improvements in 6-Minute Walk Test performance compared to low-intensity training (30%-40% of heart rate reserve). The largest changes were observed in participants who performed high-intensity training first.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic stroke (>6-month duration) and gait deficits.
effective_dosage: High-intensity (70%-80% of heart rate reserve) or low-intensity (30%-40% of heart rate reserve) locomotor training for 12 or fewer sessions.
study_duration: 4 to 5 weeks per training phase, with a 4-week washout period between phases.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of two alternative models of increased physiotherapy service delivery (seven-day week therapy or group circuit class therapy five days a week) compared to usual care for improving walking distance in stroke patients.
results_summary: Both seven-day therapy and group circuit class therapy increased physiotherapy time but showed no significant differences in walking distance compared to usual care at four weeks. Length of stay was shorter for both intervention groups, but the differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: People admitted with a diagnosis of stroke, previously independently ambulant, and with a moderate level of disability.
effective_dosage: Seven-day therapy: usual care physiotherapy provided seven days a week; circuit class therapy: two 90-minute group sessions five days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how optimized sensory cues (such as adaptive rhythmic metronomes, groove music, and bass-frequency tones) could improve gait rehabilitation in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that adaptive metronomes synchronized with patients' footsteps, improving stability and reinstating healthy gait dynamics. Other strategies like groove music and bass-frequency pulses were suggested as potent rhythmic cues to enhance motor and timing deficits.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients with motor-timing impairments in gait.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of an 8-week walking exercise program on fatigue in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study found no initial difference in fatigue between groups, but after the intervention, the walking group showed significantly lower fatigue compared to the control group. The difference was statistically significant (p = .001).
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the predictive validity of three gait assessment modes (self-reported, clinical, and quantitative) for incident falls in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that multiple gait assessment modes better identified fall risk than a single assessment, with participants showing abnormalities in at least two assessments having a higher hazard ratio for falls (HR: 1.61).
population_specificity: 380 community-dwelling older adults (mean age 76.5 ± 6.8 y, 55.8% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the minimally important difference (MID) for the Vascular Quality of Life Questionnaire (VascuQol) and the walking impairment questionnaire (WIQ) in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: The study found MID values for improvement and deterioration in VascuQol (0.87 and 0.23) and WIQ (0.11 and -0.03), aiding in interpreting treatment outcomes and setting individual care goals.
population_specificity: 294 patients with intermittent claudication (IC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of multicomponent (MCT) and resistance training (RT) programs on metabolic health parameters in healthy elderly individuals.
results_summary: The MCT program improved functional tests like chair stand and habitual walking speed, while both MCT and RT showed limited effects on metabolic health parameters, with only minor changes in specific markers like epidermal growth factor (EGF) and adiponectin.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of intramuscular transfer of pCMV-vegf165 plasmid DNA in improving walking distance and blood flow in patients with chronic lower limb ischemia.
results_summary: The pCMV-vegf165 therapy significantly increased pain-free walking distance (PWD) by 110.4% at 6 months, 167.2% at 1 year, and 190.8% at 2 years, along with improvements in ankle-brachial index (ABI) and blood flow velocity (BFV), while the control group showed no positive results.
population_specificity: Patients with atherosclerotic lower limb ischemia (moderate to severe claudication).
effective_dosage: 2 intramuscular injections of 1.2 mg pCMV-vegf165, 14 days apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional outcomes of two surgical approaches (lateral vs. posterior) for hip hemiarthroplasty in patients with intracapsular hip fractures, particularly focusing on pain, mortality, and walking ability.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between the lateral and posterior approaches in terms of mortality, residual pain, or regain of walking ability. Both approaches produced comparable functional outcomes, though the lateral approach was subjectively favored for ease of surgery.
population_specificity: 216 patients with intracapsular hip fractures undergoing cemented hemiarthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a general physical exercise program, including walking, could increase self-reported physical activity levels in patients with long-term musculoskeletal conditions.
results_summary: The study found significant increases in MET-min/week for vigorous and moderate-intensity activities, walking, and total physical activity, along with improvements in exercise frequency and functional assessments. The proportion of patients with low activity levels decreased, and functional improvements were noted in physical fitness, feelings, daily activities, and social activities.
population_specificity: 190 patients with long-term musculoskeletal conditions attending outpatient physiotherapy clinics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interventions improve community ambulation for stroke survivors and if any specific method is more effective than others.
results_summary: The study found low-quality evidence suggesting no significant effect of interventions on participation or gait speed, with wide confidence intervals indicating uncertainty. Results for secondary outcomes like the Community Walk Test and Six-Minute Walk Test also showed no clear benefit.
population_specificity: Adult stroke survivors (aged 18+) living in the community or care homes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of combining resistance training (RT) with endurance training (ET) versus ET alone in improving health outcomes for COPD patients, including walking distance.
results_summary: The study found that combining RT with ET significantly increased leg muscle strength compared to ET alone, while improvements in walking distance, exercise capacity, and HRQoL were similar between the two approaches.
population_specificity: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients (331 participants across 11 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review spine dynamic behavior during walking and assess methods for evaluating gait dynamic balance, particularly in the context of spinal deformities.
results_summary: The study identified three methods for assessing dynamic stability during gait (local-orbital dynamic stability, tri-axial accelerometry, and dynamic stability margin) and noted that conventional gait analysis techniques primarily focused on scoliosis and low back pain but lacked specific evaluation of gait dynamic balance. Further validation in spinal pathologies and clinical practice is needed.
population_specificity: Subjects with and without spinal pathologies (e.g., scoliosis, low back pain) and normal subjects for method validation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term (18-month) efficacy of supervised exercise (SE) versus stent revascularization (ST) and optimal medical care (OMC) for improving functional status and quality of life in patients with aortoiliac peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Both SE and ST significantly improved peak walking time compared to OMC, with SE showing greater improvement in claudication onset time. Quality-of-life improvements were durable and comparable between SE and ST, though some scales favored ST.
population_specificity: 111 patients with aortoiliac PAD (79 completed 18-month follow-up).
effective_dosage: 6 months of supervised exercise plus 1 year of telephone-based exercise counseling.
study_duration: 18 months (6 months active intervention, 12 months follow-up).

study_goal: To determine if eccentric exercise is effective, tolerable, and safe for adults with chronic cardiorespiratory disease.
results_summary: Eccentric exercise increased strength and mobility comparably to concentric exercise but with lower oxygen consumption and higher power output. No adverse events were reported, and pain was avoided with familiarization and individualized prescription.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic cardiorespiratory disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different posterior decompression techniques (unilateral laminotomy, bilateral laminotomy, split-spinous process laminotomy) versus conventional laminectomy for treating degenerative lumbar stenosis, particularly regarding functional disability, leg pain, and postoperative outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that different decompression techniques had similar effects on functional disability and leg pain compared to conventional laminectomy, with only perceived recovery being better in bilateral laminotomy. Postoperative low back pain was slightly less severe with bilateral and split-spinous process laminotomy, though not clinically significant. No differences were noted in complications, procedure length, hospital stay, or postoperative walking distance.
population_specificity: Individuals with symptomatic degenerative lumbar stenosis.
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up intervals varied by study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of treadmill gait training with and without visual biofeedback on gait parameters and functional capacity in stroke patients during the late recovery period.
results_summary: Both training methods improved gait and functional capacity, but the biofeedback group showed greater improvements in stance phase shortening, swing phase lengthening, and cycle length of the unaffected limb. No significant differences were found in other gait parameters or additional assessed measures.
population_specificity: Fifty individuals at least 6 months post-stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a community-based walking exercise program with training, monitoring, and coaching (TMC) components to improve exercise performance and patient-reported outcomes in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly improve peak walking time (PWT), the primary outcome, but showed improvements in claudication onset time (COT) and patient-reported outcomes via the Walking Impairment Questionnaire (WIQ). The study suggests potential benefits for secondary outcomes but requires further investigation with a larger sample size.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) who previously received peripheral endovascular therapy or presented with stable claudication (n=25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of graded activity (including moderate-intensity treadmill walking) and physiotherapy in patients with chronic nonspecific low back pain.
results_summary: Both graded activity (including walking) and physiotherapy showed significant improvements in pain intensity and disability, with no significant differences between the two interventions. The effects were similar for both treatments.
population_specificity: 66 patients with chronic nonspecific low back pain.
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity treadmill walking, twice a week for six weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how lateral wedge insoles affect the external knee adduction moment (EKAM) in individuals with medial knee osteoarthritis and identify biomechanical predictors of response.
results_summary: Lateral wedge insoles reduced EKAM in 67% of participants but increased it in 33%. Ankle joint biomechanics, particularly eversion angle and moment, were key predictors of EKAM reduction.
population_specificity: 70 participants (43 male) with medial tibiofemoral osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess improvements in head stabilization during walking in individuals with vestibular dysfunction undergoing vestibular physical therapy and virtual reality training.
results_summary: The study found that head stabilization during walking improved over time with treatment, approaching patterns similar to those of healthy controls. The method used could be adapted for portable systems to aid in gait assessment and therapy.
population_specificity: Persons with traumatic brain injury and vestibular dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review rehabilitation techniques focused on balance and walking impairment in people with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Classical rehabilitation techniques like muscle rehabilitation and neurotherapeutic facilitation were found effective, while other methods such as transcutaneal neurostimulation and robot-assisted gait rehabilitation require further study. Multidisciplinary rehabilitation programs showed positive effects, and new technologies like serious games and telerehabilitation appear promising for promoting physical activity and quality of life.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis experiencing mobility impairment.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the best treatment options for pediatric femoral shaft fractures, including the role of walking spica casts and rapid mobilization.
results_summary: The study outlines seven treatment options for pediatric femoral shaft fractures, emphasizing a shift from casting to surgical fixation and rapid mobilization, and classifies fractures into five categories to guide treatment selection.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with femoral shaft fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate treatment options for flatfoot deformity in children and specific populations like those with cerebral palsy or collagen disorders.
results_summary: The study found that nonsurgical treatments like stretching and orthotics are effective for pain management in flatfoot, while surgical options like osteotomies or arthrodesis are successful for severe cases, particularly in neuromuscular conditions. Correcting overall alignment is crucial for optimizing outcomes in valgus foot deformities.
population_specificity: Children with flatfoot, patients with cerebral palsy (walking and nonambulatory), and individuals with collagen disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aerobic walking compared to non-aerobic exercise influenced subjective memory impairment (SMI) and well-being indicators in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant impact of walking on SMI, and SMI remained stable across the intervention. However, individuals with fewer memory complaints had lower stress, fewer physical symptoms, and higher happiness levels.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (mean age = 66.4 years, n = 179).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether physical rehabilitation interventions, including walking, improve activities of daily living for people with critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP) and critical illness myopathy (CIM).
results_summary: The study found no published RCTs or quasi-RCTs examining the effects of physical rehabilitation interventions, including walking, on activities of daily living for people with CIP and CIM, concluding that large RCTs are needed.
population_specificity: People with acquired weakness syndrome due to CIP and CIM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic effects of prolonged sitting versus sitting interrupted by brief bouts of light-intensity walking over three days.
results_summary: The study found that interrupting sitting with light walking significantly lowered postprandial glucose and insulin levels compared to uninterrupted sitting, with sustained effects over three days but no further enhancement. No significant difference was observed in triglyceride levels between the two conditions.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese adults (n=19)
effective_dosage: 2 minutes of treadmill walking (3.2 km/h) every 20 minutes (17 breaks/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare postoperative recovery outcomes, including time to first walking, between laparoscopic and open ileal pouch anal anastomosis (IPAA) procedures in ulcerative colitis patients.
results_summary: Patients who underwent laparoscopic IPAA had significantly shorter times to first walking and lower postoperative inflammatory markers compared to open IPAA.
population_specificity: Patients with ulcerative colitis undergoing restorative proctocolectomy with IPAA.
study_duration: Postoperative recovery period (specific duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effectiveness of autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation following high-dose melphalan in treating POEMS syndrome, particularly in younger patients with widespread osteosclerotic lesions.
results_summary: The study found that autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation led to the disappearance of the monoclonal component and marked improvement in the patient's clinical status, including difficulty walking.
population_specificity: A 62-year-old Caucasian man with POEMS syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a home-based walking program on erectile function and the relationship between functional capacity and erectile dysfunction in low-risk post-myocardial infarction patients.
results_summary: The home-based walking group showed a 71% decrease in erectile dysfunction and significantly improved functional capacity compared to the control group, with a strong negative correlation between walking distance and erectile dysfunction.
population_specificity: Men at low cardiovascular risk after recent acute myocardial infarctions.
effective_dosage: Progressive outdoor walking program (specific frequency/distance not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether adding interferential screws to BPTB grafts in ACL reconstruction provides clinical and functional advantages in the general population.
results_summary: Both groups (with and without interferential screws) showed significant improvement in knee function (including walking), but no significant difference was found between them. Complications were minimal, with some screw-related issues in the augmented group and anterior knee laxity in the non-augmented group.
population_specificity: 66 male patients aged 21-40 with ACL-deficient knees.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of physiotherapy exercise after hospital discharge on function, walking, range of motion, quality of life, and muscle strength in patients who underwent elective primary total hip arthroplasty for osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The narrative review suggested that physiotherapy exercise after discharge may benefit patients in terms of function, walking, and muscle strengthening, but the overall quality and diversity of trials prevented meta-analyses, leaving insufficient evidence to conclusively determine effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients following elective primary total hip replacement for osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the visual exploration and balance behaviors of individuals with visual height intolerance or acrophobia during stance and locomotion at heights.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with acrophobia exhibit restricted eye and head movements, stiffened posture, cautious walking patterns, and increased anxiety when exposed to heights. These behaviors are described as tonic immobility, which may contribute to imbalance and restricted mobility.
population_specificity: Individuals with visual height intolerance or acrophobia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of physical exercise interventions on dual-task performance during walking in older adults, focusing on gait speed and relative dual-task costs.
results_summary: Physical exercise interventions significantly improved single-task gait speed, dual-task gait speed, and reduced dual-task costs, with no differences observed between cognitive-motor and motor-motor dual tasks or between active and inactive controls. However, evidence on whether these interventions reduce dual-task costs or alter dual-task strategies during walking remains lacking.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of surgery, endovascular therapy, and exercise therapy (including walking) for improving walking distance, claudication symptoms, and quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Exercise therapy (including walking) was found to improve walking distance, claudication symptoms, and quality of life compared to medical management, with high-quality evidence supporting its efficacy. However, blood flow improvements were faster and better with revascularization methods (surgery or endovascular therapy) than with exercise.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication due to peripheral arterial disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate early mobilization practices, including walking, among mechanically ventilated ICU patients and assess functional recovery at 6 months.
results_summary: Early mobilization, including walking, was uncommon (only 2% of episodes). ICU-acquired weakness was prevalent (>50% of discharged patients) and associated with higher mortality.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated ICU patients (previously functionally independent, expected ventilation >48 hours).
study_duration: First 14 days of mechanical ventilation or until extubation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively examine gait adaptations in transfemoral amputees across various walking conditions to understand dynamic instability and its impact on mobility.
results_summary: The study found that the intact limb showed significantly greater medial-lateral center-of-pressure direction changes, sensor cell loading frequency, and double support time compared to the prosthetic limb, suggesting its key role in stability. Differences in walking conditions were noted for anterior-posterior center-of-pressure direction change and double support time on the prosthetic limb, indicating adaptive gait strategies.
population_specificity: 11 individuals with unilateral transfemoral amputations

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of exercise on walking ability in patients with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking speed (measured by the 10mWT) and endurance (measured by the 6MWT and 2MWT) in pwMS who exercised, but no significant changes in the T25FW or TUG tests.
population_specificity: Adult patients with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the medical literature on 3q29 microdeletion syndrome, including its phenotypic and genetic characteristics, with a focus on associated developmental delays such as delayed walking.
results_summary: The study found that delayed walking was one of the clinical features associated with 3q29 microdeletion syndrome, alongside intellectual disability, speech delay, and musculoskeletal abnormalities. The syndrome is linked to a common 1.6 Mb chromosome deletion involving ∼30 genes.
population_specificity: A 15-year-old male with 3q29 microdeletion syndrome, alongside a review of 38 previously reported cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kinesio taping (KT) with tension could reduce pain, improve active range of motion (AROM), and enhance proprioception in patients with knee osteoarthritis during walking.
results_summary: The KT group showed significant reductions in pain during walking, increased pressure pain thresholds, and improvements in AROM and proprioception, while the placebo-KT group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Older participants (mean age 57.9 years) with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (taping applied with tension for KT group, without tension for placebo group).
study_duration: Not specified (short-term effects measured before and after intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the analgesic efficacy of oxymorphone hydrochloride (OH) and propoxyphene/acetaminophen (PA) for patients with neurogenic claudication associated with lumbar spinal stenosis during walking.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pain relief or walking tolerance among OH, PA, and placebo treatments. The trial was prematurely terminated due to PA's removal from the market, and no benefit of either opioid was demonstrated.
population_specificity: Patients with neurogenic claudication due to lumbar spinal stenosis.
effective_dosage: Single dose (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: Single-dose administration with at least 3-day washout periods between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether riociguat increased the proportion of patients achieving clinically relevant responder thresholds, such as improved 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), compared to placebo in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: Riociguat significantly increased the proportion of patients achieving 6MWD ≥380 m and improved other clinical parameters (e.g., cardiac index, functional class) compared to placebo, with no notable improvements in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Treatment-naïve patients or patients on background PAH-targeted therapy with symptomatic pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
effective_dosage: Riociguat up to 2.5 mg or 1.5 mg, 3 times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and clinical outcomes of the WheelSeeU program, a peer-led training intervention for older manual wheelchair users.
results_summary: The study assessed feasibility indicators and clinical outcomes (wheelchair skills, safety, confidence, mobility, social participation, quality of life, and health utility) at three time points, suggesting potential benefits for wheelchair use and reduced clinician burden.
population_specificity: Older adults (55+ years) who use manual wheelchairs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of an evidence-based mobility intervention on functional recovery (specifically walking >15.24m) in patients with intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) and subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) stroke.
results_summary: The mobility intervention led to a 2.3-fold increase in patients achieving walking distances >15.24m by discharge. Factors like intervention participation, initial functional level, stroke type, ICU stay duration, and absence of aphasia/hemiplegia were associated with higher likelihood of achieving this outcome.
population_specificity: Adult patients (N=361) with ICH (63.2%) or SAH stroke in a neurointensive care unit (mean age 62.1 years, 52.6% women).
effective_dosage: Daily mobility intervention based on patient's current level of function (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of neurointensive care unit stay (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between cardiovascular risk (estimated by the Framingham Risk Score) and functional capacity (measured via a 6-minute walk test) in patients with peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: The study found that higher cardiovascular risk was negatively correlated with walking distances in men and pain-free distances in women. Group B (severe risk) covered shorter distances compared to Group A (mild/moderate risk), indicating reduced functional capacity with higher cardiovascular risk.
population_specificity: 56 participants with intermittent claudication due to peripheral artery disease.

study_goal: To examine the effect of exercise therapy on the walking ability of individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Exercise therapy improved the amount of time spent walking and gait velocity, with very-low-quality evidence suggesting it may also increase the total distance walked in the 6-minute walk test compared to control interventions.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an integrative therapeutic concept combining conservative treatment (including supervised exercise therapy) with endovascular therapy for improving walking distance and health-related quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found that an integrative approach combining conservative treatment (including supervised exercise therapy) and endovascular therapy yielded the best midterm results for walking distance and quality of life. Modern technology further improved mid- and long-term patency rates, supporting the complementary nature of conservative and interventional strategies.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of real-time quantitative Doppler echocardiography (DE) in assessing cardiac preload, monitoring volume status, and improving care in acute heart failure (HF) patients.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the potential of DE in identifying inappropriate cardiac preload, monitoring volume status, and improving HF management, but does not mention any specific findings related to Walking.
population_specificity: Patients with acutely decompensated heart failure (HF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a nurse-delivered intervention could increase step-counts and moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) in older adults, adhering to WHO guidelines.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased daily step-counts (by 1,037 steps/day at 3 months) and MVPA (by 63 minutes/week at 3 months), with sustained effects at 12 months. No adverse events or negative impacts on mood, pain, or anthropometry were observed.
population_specificity: 60-75 year-olds able to increase walking, recruited from UK family practices.
effective_dosage: Four primary care nurse consultations over 3 months, incorporating behavior change techniques, pedometer/accelerometer feedback, and individualized plans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multicomponent home-based rehabilitation program (ProMo) could reduce physical disability and improve mobility in older adults after hip fracture.
results_summary: The study found no significant intervention effect on overall physical disability scores, but borderline positive effects were observed for specific activities like preparing food and handling medication. The per-protocol analysis suggested modest reductions in disability scores at 6 and 12 months.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults older than 60 years who had undergone hip fracture surgery (n = 81).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included environmental modifications, walking guidance, pain management, home exercise, and physical activity counseling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a home-based aerobic exercise regimen (cycling) on subclinical atherosclerosis and walking mobility in individuals with early-stage multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study design suggests potential benefits of aerobic exercise for improving vascular health and walking mobility in early-stage MS patients, but specific results are not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: 54 men and women with MS (Expanded Disability Status Scale score 0-4.0).
effective_dosage: 3 days/week of cycling, with gradual increases in duration and intensity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 12-week weight loss intervention with a physical activity component would lead to changes in steps/day, step count accumulation patterns, and peak cadence in overweight/obese adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in total steps/day between groups, but the physical activity intervention group showed significant increases in steps accumulated at higher cadence bands (80-99, 100-119, and 120+ steps/min) and peak 60-min cadence compared to the diet-only group.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese White and African-American adults aged 35-64 years.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of a custom-molded heel-elevated total contact insole (TCI) on rearfoot pressure reduction and heel cushion for patients with heel-reconstruction.
results_summary: The heel-elevated TCI reduced pain intensity, improved walking velocity, and healed heel ulcers in all affected patients. It also effectively reduced maximal force and plantar pressures in the heel area while shifting part of the body weight to the midfoot and forefoot.
population_specificity: Eleven patients with unilateral heel-reconstruction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify independent factors influencing mobilization progress (walking ability, stair climbing, and balance) in geriatric hip fracture patients post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that pre-fracture health status (comorbidities, functional ability, depression risk) and surgical factors (timing, duration, type) significantly influenced walking ability and stair-climbing recovery. Cognitive impairment and depressive symptoms were also key modifiable factors affecting mobility outcomes.
population_specificity: 392 hip fracture patients aged 60+ years.
study_duration: Measured outcomes at 4 days post-surgery and until discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether assessments of balance and gait could predict long-term cognitive outcomes in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found that slower Timed Up and Go test times, lower Berg Balance Scale scores, slower gait, and fewer correct answers during dual-task walking at 6 months post-stroke were significant risk markers for cognitive decline 2 years later. Multivariate analysis confirmed that Timed Up and Go times >12 seconds independently predicted cognitive decline.
population_specificity: Patients with first-ever, mild-moderate ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack from the TABASCO study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a self-regulation intervention on Theory of Planned Behavior constructs and walking behavior in general practice patients.
results_summary: The intervention showed no significant differences in perceived behavioral control, intention, attitude, or walking behavior compared to the control group. TPB variables predicted intentions to walk more but not objective walking behavior.
population_specificity: General practice patients (n = 315).
study_duration: Follow-up at post-intervention, 6 weeks, and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if oral Δ(9)-THC could slow the progression of multiple sclerosis (MS) and improve clinical trial methods for progressive MS, including assessing its safety and efficacy.
results_summary: The study found no significant treatment effect of Δ(9)-THC on primary or secondary outcomes, including disability progression and symptom scales. Safety data showed more serious adverse events in the active group (35%) compared to placebo (28%), but no major safety concerns were identified.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 with primary or secondary progressive MS, baseline EDSS 4.0-6.5, and evidence of disease progression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the need for a more rational classification system for medical elastic compression stockings (MECS) based on their properties during walking, to better inform prescribers and patients.
results_summary: The study found that current MECS classifications lack information on elastic properties and ambulatory pressure profiles, and proposed labelling MECS according to pressure and stiffness in an internationally acceptable format. It highlighted the importance of MECS performance during walking for effective compression therapy.
population_specificity: Medical experts and representatives from MECS manufacturers (attending an International Compression Club conference).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exercise therapy, including walking, on fatigue and other symptoms in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS), compared to other interventions or passive controls.
results_summary: Exercise therapy, including walking, reduced fatigue and improved sleep, physical functioning, and self-perceived health in CFS patients, with no significant safety concerns. Its effectiveness was similar to cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and greater than pacing or supportive listening.
population_specificity: Adults with a primary diagnosis of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS), diagnosed using CDC (1994) or Oxford criteria.
effective_dosage: Mixed intensity aerobic exercise (e.g., walking, swimming, cycling) for 12–26 weeks; exact walking dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the aetiology of plantar fasciitis and discuss its diagnosis, examination, and management through a case study.
results_summary: The abstract states that plantar fasciitis is a self-limiting condition that usually resolves within 12 months after conservative treatment, exacerbated by weight bearing after rest.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mention of individuals with plantar fasciitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week combined physical exercise training (including walking) and nutritional intervention improves physical performance and health-related quality of life in prefrail elderly women.
results_summary: The combined intervention improved physical performance (handgrip strength) and several domains of health-related quality of life, but these benefits were not sustained at the 6-month follow-up. The exercise-only group showed improved handgrip strength post-intervention.
population_specificity: Prefrail women aged 70 years or older living in the community.
effective_dosage: Exercise training (including walking) once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of exercise and MFGM supplementation on frailty, physical function, and hematological parameters in elderly women.
results_summary: The study found that combined exercise and MFGM supplementation significantly improved frailty reversal rates, walking speed, and physical function, with the highest benefits observed in the exercise+MFGM group.
population_specificity: Frail, elderly Japanese women over 75 years of age.
study_duration: 3 months of intervention, with a 4-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a computer-tailored, pedometer-based physical activity intervention in increasing walking among working adults, particularly those not meeting daily step recommendations.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased daily step counts in both the total and at-risk samples at 1-month and 3-month follow-ups, with the at-risk group showing a notable increase of 1056 steps/day compared to a decrease in the control group. Self-reported walking time also improved in the at-risk sample at 1 month, though this effect was not sustained at 3 months.
population_specificity: Working adults (≥18 years) from eight Flemish workplaces, with a focus on those not reaching 10,000 steps/day at baseline.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included a pedometer, informational booklet, and tailored step advice).
study_duration: 3 months (with assessments at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the associations among changes in physical fitness, walking-related physical activity levels (PAL), and fatigue in children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: In children with bilateral CP, physical fitness parameters showed a positive, significant association with walking-related PAL, but no such associations were found in children with unilateral CP. No clinically relevant association between physical fitness and fatigue was observed.
population_specificity: Children aged 7 to 13 years with bilateral or unilateral spastic CP who were able to walk.
study_duration: Measurements were taken at baseline, 6 months (after intervention), and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of ankle taping on ankle-joint coupling during walking and jogging in young adults with and without chronic ankle instability (CAI).
results_summary: Ankle taping significantly reduced the magnitude of coupled motion and variability (VCV) during walking and jogging in both CAI and healthy groups, suggesting a protective mechanism. No differences were found in the ratio of coupled motion (theta) between taped and non-taped conditions.
population_specificity: 12 patients with CAI and 11 healthy controls (young adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effects of peroneal nerve functional electrical stimulation (FES) and ankle foot orthoses (AFOs) on gait quality and function in individuals with foot drop poststroke over a 12-month period.
results_summary: Both FES and AFOs showed equivalent improvements in gait speed, with FES demonstrating additional benefits in walking endurance and functional ambulation. No statistically significant differences were found between the two treatments for primary or secondary endpoints.
population_specificity: Individuals with foot drop poststroke.
effective_dosage: Not specified (subjects used study devices for all home and community ambulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term evolution of walking ability and quality of life in patients treated with hip resurfacing arthroplasty and determine if age at surgery influenced these outcomes.
results_summary: Walking ability was maintained through the last follow-up at a minimum of 10 years post-surgery, despite a slight decline in overall physical function. Pain relief and quality of life were also sustained over time.
population_specificity: 100 patients with unilateral, unrevised, Charnley class A metal-on-metal hip resurfacing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of intensive locomotor training for improving walking ability in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injuries.
results_summary: The study found that intensive locomotor training improved walking ability in patients with incomplete spinal cord injuries, contributing to enhanced functional independence and quality of life.
population_specificity: Individuals with incomplete spinal cord injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the surgical and functional outcomes of patients with Grade 3 open tibial fractures treated with circular frames, including their ability to walk and perform daily activities.
results_summary: The study found that circular frames resulted in good or excellent functional outcomes in over half of the patients, with no re-fractures or amputations. However, 36% reported walking difficulties, and 41% had pain issues, while EQ-5D scores were comparable to the general UK population.
population_specificity: 22 patients with Grade 3 open tibial fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of tango, treadmill training, and stretching on locomotor function in individuals with Parkinson's disease and explore how these interventions alter brain connectivity.
results_summary: The study found that tango and treadmill training improved gait, balance, disease severity, and quality of life in Parkinson's patients, with neuroimaging used to explore underlying neural mechanisms.
population_specificity: 120 right-handed individuals with idiopathic Parkinson's disease, aged 30 or older.
study_duration: 3 months of exercise training, with follow-up at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of combined aerobic and strength training versus aerobic-only training (walking) on cognitive and motor function in institutionalized dementia patients and explore if motor improvements mediate cognitive improvements.
results_summary: Combined training showed greater improvements in global cognition, memory, executive function, walking endurance, strength, and balance compared to social visits, while aerobic-only training improved only executive function. Follow-up effects diminished over time, and motor improvements did not mediate cognitive improvements.
population_specificity: Institutionalized dementia patients (age 85.5 ± 5.1 years) in a psycho-geriatric nursing home.
effective_dosage: Four 30-minute walking sessions per week (aerobic group).

study_goal: To determine the effect of a 12-week LBPP-supported low-load treadmill walking program on knee joint pain, function, and thigh muscle strength in overweight patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Participants reported significant improvements in knee joint pain and function, demonstrated increased thigh muscle strength, and required less LBPP support to walk pain-free. The regimen effectively reduced acute knee pain during walking and improved daily joint symptoms.
population_specificity: Overweight patients aged 55-75 with mild-to-moderate knee osteoarthritis (BMI ≥25 kg/m).
effective_dosage: LBPP-supported low-load treadmill walking (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms and effectiveness of locomotor training and stimulation therapies (e.g., motor cortex, spinal cord, peripheral nerve) in improving walking recovery after spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that intensive locomotor training improves walking recovery in people with incomplete spinal cord injury, with over 90% recovering walking ability. Stimulation therapies (e.g., epidural spinal cord stimulation, motor cortex stimulation) modulate spinal cord excitability and may facilitate synaptic formation and motor recovery.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (primarily incomplete injuries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence of metabolic syndrome (MetS) and its association with physical capacity, disability, and self-rated health in older adults at high risk of mobility disability.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in 400-m walk time, SPPB score, or disability score between participants with and without MetS, but MetS was associated with stronger grip strength and poorer self-rated health in the overall sample.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling sedentary adults aged 70 to 89 at high risk of mobility disability (SPPB score ≤9).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and outcomes of using gait trainers (walkers with trunk and pelvic support) for children unable to walk independently or with hand-held walkers.
results_summary: The study found mixed but generally positive evidence, with some studies reporting increased walking distance, steps, mobility level, and benefits to bowel function and bone mineral density, though the overall evidence was primarily descriptive and insufficient for firm conclusions.
population_specificity: Children with mobility limitations who cannot walk independently or with hand-held walkers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation (TEAS) for treating muscle spasticity after brain injury, including its impact on walking capability.
results_summary: The study found that 100 Hz TEAS significantly reduced wrist spasticity at weeks 2, 3, and 4 of treatment and at 1-month follow-up, but other endpoints, including walking capability, were unaffected. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 60 patients with muscle spasticity after brain injury
effective_dosage: 0, 2, or 100 Hz TEAS applied 5 times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of partial body weight supported treadmill training versus over ground training for improving walking ability in children with mild to moderate cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in walking ability between the two training methods by week 8, though the intervention group showed greater improvement in walking speed by week 4. All outcomes improved significantly over time, with further gains observed by week 8.
population_specificity: Thirty children with cerebral palsy (aged 6-18, Gross Motor Function Classification System score II-III).
effective_dosage: Two 30-minute sessions per week for 8 weeks.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of an exercise specialist-led lifestyle program targeting increased daily walking and dietary changes for adults with type 2 diabetes in primary care.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased daily steps at 3 and 6 months compared to the control group, but no significant differences were observed for diet or clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with recently diagnosed type 2 diabetes (mean age 59.5 years, 51% women).
effective_dosage: Individualized daily pedometer step goals for the first 3 months, followed by brisk walking speed for the next 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether functional electrical stimulation (FES) improves activity, particularly in comparison to no intervention or training alone, with a focus on walking speed and upper-limb activity.
results_summary: FES moderately improved activity compared to no intervention or training alone, with a large effect on upper-limb activity and a small effect on walking speed. The findings support the use of FES in stroke rehabilitation to enhance activity performance.
population_specificity: Stroke rehabilitation patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether clinical phenotypes (airway obstructive vs. parenchymal destructive COPD) influence outcomes of pulmonary rehabilitation programs, including walking performance.
results_summary: The study found that pulmonary rehabilitation significantly improved 6-minute walking distance and other outcomes in COPD patients, with no differences between the two clinical phenotypes.
population_specificity: 364 COPD patients (70 ± 8 years, 76.3% males) in 6 Italian centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal ghrelin dose for improving exercise tolerance and oxygen uptake capacity in cachectic patients with chronic respiratory failure.
results_summary: Both 1 μg/kg and 2 μg/kg ghrelin doses similarly improved 6-minute walking distance, but the 2 μg/kg dose significantly enhanced peak VO2 and other secondary outcomes like food intake and lean body mass. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Cachectic patients with chronic respiratory failure.
effective_dosage: 1 μg/kg or 2 μg/kg ghrelin, administered intravenously twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of an early cardiac rehabilitation program, primarily centered on progressive walking, on health-related quality of life and functional capacity in low-risk patients recovering from acute myocardial infarction.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly higher health-related quality of life scores and greater functional capacity (measured by 6-minute walk test distance) compared to the control group 30 days after discharge.
population_specificity: Low-risk patients who recently experienced an acute myocardial infarction.
effective_dosage: Progressive walking program (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the association between gait and cognition, present dual-task test paradigms, and provide an algorithm for standardized mobility tests in older adults.
results_summary: The study recommends performing at least two mobility assessments in patients aged 65+ to detect gait and cognitive deficits early, with abnormal results prompting referral to a gait specialist for further analysis. Early detection allows for timely interventions to improve gait and cognition.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of an articulated ankle-foot orthosis versus a rigid carbon fiber footplate attached to a foot orthosis in controlling idiopathic toe walking in children.
results_summary: Both orthoses improved kinematics, but the foot orthosis group sustained improvements even after removal, while the ankle-foot orthosis group did not. Parents preferred the foot orthosis for ease of use and appearance.
population_specificity: 18 children with idiopathic toe walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the benefits of replacing sitting time with walking and other activities on mortality risk in older adults.
results_summary: Replacing 1 hour of sitting with walking or other nonexercise activities was associated with lower all-cause mortality (HR, 0.70 (0.66-0.74)) in less active adults. No significant benefit was observed for nonexercise activities in more active participants.
population_specificity: 154,614 older adults (59-82 years) with no major chronic diseases at baseline.
effective_dosage: Not specified (replacement of 1 h·d(-1) of sitting with activity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine age-related differences in frontal plane dynamic stability during walking by comparing margin of stability and hip abductor moment generation between young and older adults performing lateral steps.
results_summary: Older adults exhibited 42% larger peak hip abductor moments and greater stability across all step targets compared to younger adults, despite slower execution. The findings suggest older adults may use compensatory strategies to maintain stability during lateral stepping tasks.
population_specificity: 19 young adults (22.9±3.1 years) and 18 older adults (72.8±5.2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the management techniques for extensor mechanism disruption in total knee arthroplasty, including the role of walking aids and surgical options.
results_summary: The study found that nonsurgical management (walking aids/knee braces) may not be suitable for active patients, while surgical options like repair or reconstruction have inconsistent outcomes. Synthetic material reconstructions show promise but require further study.
population_specificity: Patients with extensor mechanism disruption following total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a 6-week nonsurgical, multimodal program for improving outcomes in patients with neurogenic claudication, focusing on pain, disability, walking ability, and treatment satisfaction.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant and clinically important improvements in pain, disability, and walking ability, as measured by the Oswestry Disability Index and Swiss Spinal Stenosis Questionnaire. Patients reported high treatment satisfaction.
population_specificity: 49 patients with neurogenic claudication, mean age 70 years.
effective_dosage: Manual therapy twice per week, structured home-based exercises, and self-management strategies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of diagnostic motor nerve block with anaesthetics and selective tibial neurotomy in treating spastic equinovarus foot in hemiplegic adults.
results_summary: Both diagnostic nerve block and selective tibial neurotomy similarly reduced spasticity and improved gait kinematics, but neurotomy showed additional long-term benefits in gait speed and tibialis anterior muscle strength.
population_specificity: Hemiplegic adults with spastic equinovarus foot.
study_duration: Assessments were conducted before and after the nerve block, and at two months and two years post-neurotomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of walking versus balance training on fall prevention among community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The walking group showed a significant reduction in fall risk compared to the balance group when measured per physically active person-day and person-step, but walking also increased the number of trips.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 65-79 years in Japan.
study_duration: 3-month supervised and 13-month unsupervised program (16 months total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term safety and efficacy of riociguat in improving exercise capacity (measured by 6-min walking distance) and functional class in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that riociguat was well tolerated and led to sustained improvements in 6-min walking distance and WHO functional class for up to 1 year, with 33% of patients showing improvement, 61% stabilizing, and 6% worsening.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension, either treatment-naïve or pretreated with endothelin-receptor antagonists or prostanoids.
effective_dosage: Individually adjusted up to a maximum of 2.5 mg three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a pre-bariatric surgery physical activity intervention (PAI) focused on increasing walking exercise could improve health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in candidates for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The PAI group significantly increased bout-related moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and reported greater improvements in most HRQoL scales compared to the standard care group. Greater increases in MVPA were associated with better post-intervention HRQoL outcomes in physical function, bodily pain, and general health.
population_specificity: Adult bariatric surgery candidates (86.7% female, BMI = 45.0 ± 6.5 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 6 individual weekly counseling sessions to increase walking exercise (specific walking duration/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of the HiBalance program, a challenging balance-training regimen, compared with usual care in elderly individuals with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The HiBalance program significantly improved balance and gait performance compared to usual care, with favorable effects on physical activity levels and activities of daily living, though no group differences were found for concerns about falling.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease (n = 100, with 91 completing the study).
effective_dosage: 10-week HiBalance program (specific frequency not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the health benefits of outdoor walking groups by analyzing physiological, psychological, and well-being outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that walking groups significantly improved cardiovascular health (reduced blood pressure, resting heart rate), body composition (reduced body fat, BMI), cholesterol levels, and mental health (reduced depression scores). No notable adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Adults participating in outdoor walking groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost-effectiveness of X-stop versus minimally invasive decompression in patients with symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis.
results_summary: The study found that X-stop had a significantly higher reoperation rate (33%) and higher costs compared to minimally invasive decompression, with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio of €25,700 per quality-adjusted life-year. The majority of bootstrap samples suggested a 50% likelihood that X-stop is cost-effective at this extra cost.
population_specificity: Patients aged 50-85 years with neurogenic intermittent claudication within a 250-meter walking distance and 1- or 2-level lumbar spinal stenosis.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the pharmacological, efficacy, and tolerability of pirfenidone in treating idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that pirfenidone reduced the rate of decline in forced vital capacity (FVC) and improved 6-min walking test distance and progression-free survival in IPF patients. It also showed a manageable tolerability profile with mild to moderate adverse events.
population_specificity: Adults with mild to moderate idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a Facebook social support group could effectively increase daily steps (physical activity) in young women compared to a standard walking intervention.
results_summary: Both intervention groups significantly increased daily steps, but the Facebook Social Support Group showed a greater increase (from 5,295 to 12,472 steps/day) compared to the Standard Walking Intervention. The results suggest Facebook-based social support may enhance physical activity outcomes in young women.
population_specificity: Female college freshmen (N = 63).
effective_dosage: Weekly step goals (specific numbers not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effects of increased physical activity, including walking, on IBS symptoms and psychological well-being.
results_summary: The study found that increased physical activity, including walking, significantly improved IBS symptoms and psychological symptoms like quality of life, fatigue, depression, and anxiety over a median follow-up of 5.2 years. Physical activity time increased from 3.2 to 5.2 hours per week, with walking being one of the most common activities.
population_specificity: 39 IBS patients (32 women, median age 45 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (physical activity increased from 3.2 to 5.2 hours per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking training combined with virtual reality-based training effectively increases walking speed in chronic stroke patients and if it outperforms non-virtual reality walking interventions.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that virtual reality-based walking training increased walking speed by 0.17 m/s compared to placebo/nothing and by 0.15 m/s compared to non-virtual reality walking interventions, demonstrating its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether therapeutic Tai Chi, combined with general physical therapy, improves balance, gait, and quality of life in chronic stroke patients compared to general physical therapy alone.
results_summary: The Tai Chi group showed greater improvements in balance, gait, and quality of life compared to the control group, with significant enhancements in functional reach, dynamic gait index, 10-m walking test, timed up-and-go test, and multiple SF-36 survey items.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (22 inpatients, divided into two groups).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes of therapeutic Tai Chi (10 different movements), twice per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining walking (exercise) with psychotherapy was more effective than psychotherapy alone or standard care in reducing acute depressive symptoms in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the group receiving both walking and psychotherapy (STEP) showed significantly greater improvement in depression scores compared to the group receiving only psychotherapy (TALK) or standard care, with the TALK group also outperforming the control group.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 50-89 years) receiving treatment in inpatient psychiatric units.
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing physical activity, such as walking, during inpatient rehabilitation improves mobility outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that enhanced physical activity would lead to better mobility outcomes, measured by self-selected gait speed and other mobility indices, but results were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older adults (age >60 years) undergoing inpatient rehabilitation for mobility improvement in Australian hospitals.
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants spent time each week performing additional physical activities like standing or walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of dalfampridine-ER in improving walking speed in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that dalfampridine-ER improved walking speed in responders, with effects sustained over time compared to non-responders. No new safety signals emerged, and tolerability was consistent with previous trials.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current biomarkers for early diagnosis and monitoring of Parkinson's disease (PD), focusing on oxidative stress, protein aggregation, and inflammation.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the need for reliable PD biomarkers and reviews potential candidates in bodily fluids, but does not present specific findings related to walking or its effects.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between balance and dual task performance in adults over 80 years and compare differences between fallers and non-fallers.
results_summary: Significant correlations were found between balance and dual task variables. Fallers took more time and steps during dual task tests, but no significant differences in balance tests were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged over 80 years who were able to walk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of walking on cardiovascular disease risk factors through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized control trials.
results_summary: Walking interventions significantly improved aerobic capacity, reduced blood pressure, waist circumference, weight, body fat percentage, and BMI, but did not affect blood lipids. The findings highlight walking as an effective health promotion activity.
population_specificity: Inactive participants at baseline.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking as the only treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the evidence on the correlation between peak aerobic capacity (V̇o₂peak) and walking capacity (speed and distance) in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a low correlation (rɱ = .42) between V̇o₂peak and walking speed and a moderate correlation (rɱ = .52) between V̇o₂peak and walking distance, suggesting other factors also influence walking capacity post-stroke. The included studies had small sample sizes and low methodological quality.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide recommendations for physical therapists to improve the identification and management of fall risk in community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The study synthesized existing clinical practice guidelines, recommending screening for falls, balance, and mobility impairments, followed by targeted multifactorial assessment and intervention for at-risk older adults. It highlighted gaps in physical therapy-specific guidelines for precise recommendations.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and outcomes of X-Stop versus minimally invasive decompression (MID) in treating neurogenic intermittent claudication due to lumbar spinal stenosis.
results_summary: Both MID and X-Stop significantly improved symptoms with no clinical differences in effectiveness at any follow-up point, but X-Stop had a significantly higher risk of secondary surgery. Complication rates were similar but more severe for MID.
population_specificity: Patients aged 50-85 with neurogenic intermittent claudication within a 250-m walking distance and 1- or 2-level lumbar spinal stenosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 48-week walking program could reduce falls in older people and improve secondary outcomes like quality of life and physical activity levels.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in fall rates between the walking intervention and control groups, but the intervention group increased their exercise and walking time significantly.
population_specificity: Physically inactive community-dwelling adults aged 65+ years.
effective_dosage: Self-paced walking program with three mailed manuals and telephone coaching (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Tizanidine, an anti-spastic medication, could improve walking endurance in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in walking endurance for the high-functioning group, with some subjects showing clinically meaningful improvements. Baseline walking endurance was a strong predictor of recovery.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) experiencing spasticity in ankle muscles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare cortical activity during user-driven (active) treadmill walking versus passive treadmill walking to assess mental engagement and potential training benefits.
results_summary: Active walking resulted in statistically significant decreases in spectral power (desynchronization) in the anterior cingulate, sensorimotor cortices, and posterior parietal lobe, indicating greater motor cortex engagement compared to passive treadmill walking.
population_specificity: Nine healthy subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of pharmacological (tizanidine) and physical (robotic-assisted locomotor training) interventions on walking function in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Both interventions showed improvements in walking speed, endurance, and mobility, particularly in high-functioning subjects, but clinically meaningful improvements were seen in only about 10% of participants. No significant differences were found between the interventions.
population_specificity: Individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a smartphone app for the 2-6MWT that provides additional movement data beyond traditional walk tests.
results_summary: The app accurately identified foot strikes (within 0.07 seconds of video recordings) and calculated total walking distance within 1m of measured distance. It also provided new data on step timing and pelvis accelerations, which are not available in standard 2-6MWTs.
population_specificity: Five able-bodied participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of two physical therapy interventions (strength training and movement strategy training combined with falls prevention education) in reducing falls in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Both intervention groups (strength training and movement strategy training) showed significant reductions in falls compared to the control group, with strength training reducing falls by 84.9% and movement strategy training by 61.5%. Disability scores also improved in the intervention groups while deteriorating in the control group.
population_specificity: People with mild to moderately severe Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: 8 weeks of outpatient therapy once per week plus a structured home program.
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention, with falls recorded over 12 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pregabalin for treating pain and pain on walking in patients with painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference between pregabalin and placebo for co-primary endpoints (mean DPN pain and pain on walking), but period 1 analysis showed significant improvements. Pregabalin improved patient global impression of change and sleep interference compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) who experienced pain while walking.
study_duration: Two 6-week treatment periods separated by a 2-week washout period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of an 8-week aerobic walking protocol on insulin resistance in women with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found that the walking protocol significantly reduced insulin resistance, fasting glucose, and plasma insulin levels, with notable improvements in waist and hip circumference and BMI. The exercise group showed significant interaction effects over time compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 53 women with type 2 diabetes mellitus, divided into exercise (n=27) and control (n=26) groups.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of walking at 60% maximum heart rate intensity, 3 times per week, preceded by 10 minutes of warm-up and followed by 10 minutes of stretching.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of lunchtime walks on momentary work affect at both individual and group levels in physically inactive employees.
results_summary: Lunchtime walks improved enthusiasm, relaxation, and nervousness at work, though results varied between between-group and within-person analyses. The intervention effectively altered some affective states, suggesting potential benefits for public health and workplace performance.
population_specificity: Physically inactive employees (N=56; 92.86% female; mean age 47.68) from a UK university.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence and risk factors for pituitary hormone deficiencies in childhood cancer survivors treated with cranial radiotherapy and evaluate the impact of untreated deficiencies on health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found high prevalence rates of growth hormone deficiency (46.5%) and other pituitary deficiencies, with untreated deficiencies associated with adverse health outcomes like decreased muscle mass, exercise tolerance, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and slow walking.
population_specificity: Childhood cancer survivors (mean age 34.2 years) treated with cranial radiotherapy.
study_duration: Mean follow-up of 27.3 years (range 10.8 to 47.7 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of community-wide, multi-strategic interventions on population levels of physical activity, including walking.
