results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in physical activity at the population level, though some interventions with environmental components observed more people walking. The better-designed studies showed no improvement in primary outcomes, and reporting bias was evident.
population_specificity: Communities in high-income (25 studies) and low-income (8 studies) countries, with populations ranging from 500 to 1.9 million.
study_duration: Minimum six-month follow-up from the start of the intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare 3D kinematic patterns during walking between individuals who underwent ACL reconstruction (ACLR), their healthy contralateral knees, and a healthy control group.
results_summary: ACLR knees showed improved extension compared to ACL-deficient knees but still had a deficit compared to healthy controls. No significant differences were found in axial plane kinematics pre- and post-operation, but ACLR knees differed from controls at specific gait cycle intervals.
population_specificity: 15 patients pre- and post-ACLR, 15 contralateral knees, and 15 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week exercise program focused on improving dynamic postural stability in people with Parkinson's disease is more effective than education, benefits from increased training frequency, and provides long-term benefits.
results_summary: The study suggests that low-intensity, progressive trunk exercises may improve postural stability in people with Parkinson's disease, with potential for easy implementation at home or under professional guidance. Final results will confirm efficacy compared to education and the impact of training frequency.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling individuals diagnosed with idiopathic Parkinson's disease and a history of falls.
effective_dosage: Exercise once per week or 3 days per week.
study_duration: 12-week intervention followed by a 12-week sustainability period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) and identify risk factors for comorbid depression in COPD patients, including the role of physical activity as measured by the 6-minute walking test (6-MWT).
results_summary: The study found that COPD patients with depression had higher HADS scores, but the HADS exhibited low diagnostic accuracy for depression. The 6-MWT was evaluated as part of the assessment but its specific efficacy or safety was not the primary focus.
population_specificity: COPD patients (GOLD stage I-IV, 40-75 years old, mean age 62.5 years, 32% female, mean FEV1 48% predicted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of the built environment on active commuting to school and daily physical activity outcomes in children participating in a walking school bus study.
results_summary: The study found no differences in built environments between control and intervention schools. Park space was inversely associated with active commuting, while mixed-land use and high traffic volume/street connectivity were positively associated with moderate-to-vigorous physical activity.
population_specificity: Children participating in a walking school bus randomized controlled trial (control n=4, intervention n=4 schools).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors, including walking speed, that predict poor hospital outcomes (e.g., length of stay, mortality, institutionalization) in older patients admitted to acute care wards.
results_summary: Walking speed was identified as an independent predictor of length of hospital stay, suggesting that slower walking speed is associated with prolonged hospitalization. The study did not evaluate walking as an intervention but as a predictive factor for outcomes.
population_specificity: Older patients (aged 65+ years) admitted to geriatric and internal medicine acute care wards in seven Italian hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic efficacy of surgery (with or without adjuvant radiotherapy) versus radiotherapy alone in treating metastatic spinal cord compression (MSCC), particularly focusing on outcomes like ambulation, pain relief, and survival.
results_summary: Surgery (with or without adjuvant radiotherapy) improved ambulation, pain relief, and 1-year survival compared to radiotherapy alone, but no differences were observed in regaining walking ability, and surgery was associated with longer hospital stays.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic spinal cord compression (MSCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the benefits of yoga intervention during pregnancy to other physical exercises, including walking.
results_summary: The study found that yoga was more effective than walking or standard prenatal exercises in reducing prenatal disorders, pain, stress, and improving relationship scores. Walking was not specifically evaluated for safety or efficacy in this context.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, including those who are depressed, high-risk, or experiencing lumbopelvic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week neuromuscular exercise program could reduce the peak knee adduction moment (a measure of knee load distribution) during walking and one-leg sit-to-stand in individuals who had undergone medial arthroscopic partial meniscectomy (APM) within the past 3-12 months.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in the peak knee adduction moment during walking or one-leg sit-to-stand between the exercise and control groups. There were also no significant differences in secondary outcomes, indicating the exercise program did not alter knee load distribution or other measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 30-50 years with no to mild pain after medial APM within the past 3-12 months.
effective_dosage: Eight individual physiotherapist-guided sessions plus home exercises over 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the comparative effectiveness and safety of unilateral lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS) with lobe versus sublobe resection in patients with pulmonary emphysema.
results_summary: The study found that both lobe and sublobe resections improved lung function and 6-minute walking distance, with lobe resection showing better long-term reduction in lung hyperinflation after 1 year. Complication rates were similar, and there was no mortality within 90 days postsurgery.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary emphysema (mean age 62.1 ± 8.9 years, range 41-79).
study_duration: Follow-up at 90 days and 1 year postsurgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking training with cueing of cadence is more effective than walking training alone in improving walking speed, stride length, cadence, and symmetry in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that walking training with cueing of cadence significantly improved walking speed, stride length, cadence, and symmetry compared to walking training alone, with clinically meaningful effect sizes. The evidence supports recommending this intervention for moderately disabled stroke survivors.
population_specificity: Adults who have had a stroke.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of cueing of cadence, four times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an exercise plus Social Cognitive Theory-based behavior change intervention versus an exercise plus control education intervention on walking mobility in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study will assess walking mobility and secondary outcomes like aerobic capacity, muscle strength, and exercise adherence at multiple time points, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The trial is designed to inform sustainable exercise interventions for MS patients.
population_specificity: People with MS who walk independently, are physically inactive, and have not had a relapse or medication change in the last 12 weeks.
study_duration: 10-week intervention with follow-up assessments at weeks 12, 24, and 36.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of progressive resistance training (RT), with or without protein and vitamin supplementation (RTS), or cognitive training (CT), on DNA damage and antioxidant enzyme activities in institutionalized elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that both RT and CT improved resistance against H2O2-induced DNA damage, while nutritional supplementation did not provide additional protective effects. Basal DNA damage increased significantly after 3 months in the RT and RTS groups, but antioxidant enzyme activities improved in these groups over time.
population_specificity: 105 institutionalized Austrian women and men aged 65-98 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking; resistance training and cognitive training interventions were used.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness and safety of local intramuscular transplantation of autologous adult bone marrow mononuclear cells (BMMNCs) as a treatment for critical limb ischaemia (CLI).
results_summary: The treatment group showed a significantly smaller proportion of participants undergoing amputation compared with the control group in one study, while the other study reported greater pain reduction, increased ankle brachial index, and improved pain-free walking distance in the treatment group. However, the authors concluded that there is insufficient evidence to support this treatment due to the small number of participants and limited trials.
population_specificity: Patients with critical limb ischaemia (CLI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a new physiotherapy approach, including side-alternating whole-body vibration, on motor function in children with osteogenesis imperfecta (OI).
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in motor function (GMFM-66 score) and walking distance after 12 months of treatment, along with improved bone mineral density.
population_specificity: Children with osteogenesis imperfecta (53 participants, aged 2.54–24.81 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (included 6 months of side-alternating whole-body vibration training, physiotherapy, resistance training, and treadmill training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if self-reported walking speed could serve as a reliable marker for objectively measured walking speed in assessing sarcopenia and frailty.
results_summary: The study found a strong association between self-reported and measured walking speeds, with both similarly linked to clinical characteristics and mortality. Slower walking speeds (self-reported and measured) were associated with poorer physical function, increased medication use, and higher mortality risk.
population_specificity: 730 men and 999 women aged 61 to 73 years from the Hertfordshire Cohort Study.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking speed was measured, not prescribed).
study_duration: Not specified (cross-sectional analysis with mortality follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an early mobility protocol increased mobility and improved clinical and psychological outcomes in critically ill patients with primary neurologic injury.
results_summary: The study found that postintervention patients had higher mobility levels, decreased hospital and neurologic ICU length of stay, and were more likely to be discharged home, with reduced rates of bloodstream infections, hospital-acquired pressure ulcers, and anxiety, but no change in mortality or other complications.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with primary neurologic injury admitted to a neurologic ICU.
study_duration: 4 months pre- and postintervention with a 4-month run-in period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of robotically assisted body weight supported treadmill training (RABWSTT) for improving cardiovascular fitness in individuals with chronic motor incomplete spinal cord injury (CMISCI).
results_summary: The RABWSTT group showed a significant 12.3% improvement in peak VO(2) during robotic treadmill walking, while the home stretching program group had a non-significant 3.9% change. No significant changes were observed in peak VO(2) during arm cycle ergometry for either group.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic motor incomplete spinal cord injury (ASIA level C4-L2, at least one-year post-injury).
effective_dosage: Three times per week for three months.
study_duration: Three months (with an additional three months for the crossover group).

study_goal: The researchers were not studying Walking; the abstract discusses targeting miR-122 as a potential treatment for Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Walking or its effects; it focuses on the potential of antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) targeting miR-122 as a new anti-HCV treatment.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study does not involve Walking).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study does not involve Walking).
study_duration: Not applicable (study does not involve Walking).

study_goal: The researchers examined the etiology of toenail onycholysis, particularly its mechanical causes related to walking and foot pressure.
results_summary: The study found that toenail onycholysis is primarily mechanical, caused by pressure from closed shoes during walking, especially in individuals with uneven flat feet leading to asymmetric gait.
population_specificity: Individuals with toenail onycholysis, particularly those with flat feet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationships among balance and mobility measures in children with unilateral lower-limb amputation compared to able-bodied children.
results_summary: Children with lower-limb amputation showed significantly reduced walking speed, distance, and functional balance compared to able-bodied children. Better postural control and balance were associated with faster walking speeds in the amputation group.
population_specificity: Children with unilateral lower-limb amputation (n=10) and age-matched able-bodied children (n=10).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the reliability and validity of using the Lokomat robotic exoskeleton to quantitatively measure static position sense of the legs in persons with incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found that the Lokomat-based assessment was reliable and valid for measuring joint position sense in individuals with incomplete SCI, showing significantly greater and more variable errors in SCI subjects compared to able-bodied subjects. Error scores correlated with clinical measures of joint position sense.
population_specificity: 23 able-bodied subjects and 23 persons with incomplete SCI (American Spinal Injury Association Impairment Scale level B, C, or D).
study_duration: Not specified (subjects were tested twice for reliability).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological properties, clinical efficacy, and safety of dalfampridine (DAL) in improving walking ability and speed in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: DAL improved walking ability in approximately one-third of patients and walking speed in about 25% of patients, independent of disease course, compared to placebo. It also enhanced leg strength but carried a dose-dependent risk of seizures, particularly at dosages exceeding 10 mg twice daily.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand barriers and facilitators to engagement with a primary care-based walking intervention using pedometers and behavior change techniques.
results_summary: Most participants felt they benefited from the intervention, regardless of step-count changes, with key facilitators including health motivation and support, while barriers included physical health problems and time constraints. Behavior change techniques like self-monitoring and goal-setting were impactful, whereas rewards were not helpful.
population_specificity: Mid-life and older adults in the UK not meeting recommended physical activity levels.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pedometer and handbook with/without nurse support).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dopaminergic drugs on arm swing velocity, symmetry, and coordination in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients during walking.
results_summary: PD subjects in the OFF-medication state showed reduced arm swing amplitude and increased asymmetry compared to controls, which improved with dopaminergic treatment. However, bilateral arm coordination did not change with medication, suggesting involvement of other neurotransmitters.
population_specificity: 16 PD patients and 17 control subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the objectivity, cross-cultural validity, and convergent validity of the Vestibular Activities and Participation (VAP) questionnaire, including its relevance to walking-related activities, across four countries.
results_summary: The study identified walking long distances as part of Subscale 2 in the VAP questionnaire, showing a moderate correlation (0.64) with the Dizziness Handicap Inventory, indicating its utility in assessing activity limitations due to vertigo and dizziness. The questionnaire demonstrated intercultural adaptability and psychometric soundness for clinical and research use.
population_specificity: 453 participants from specialized outpatient dizziness clinics in Germany, the United States, Jordan, and Saudi Arabia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 12-week exercise program (including aerobic, resistance, and core stability exercises) improved fatigue, pain, activity, and participation in adults with Pompe disease.
results_summary: The study found that fatigue and pain levels improved significantly after the 12-week program, but motor function and physical activity levels did not change. Improvements in fatigue and pain were not linked to gains in aerobic fitness or muscle strength.
population_specificity: Mildly affected adult patients with Pompe disease who were not dependent on ventilators or walking devices and were receiving enzyme replacement therapy.
effective_dosage: 36 sessions of standardized aerobic, resistance, and core stability exercises over 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether supervised exercise therapy (SET) increases physical activity levels and ambulatory activities in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: SET led to more patients meeting the minimum PA recommendations (43% to 63%) and improved walking distances (PFWD and MWD), but no significant increase in mean daily PA levels, steps, or ambulatory activity duration was observed.
population_specificity: Patients newly diagnosed with intermittent claudication (IC).
effective_dosage: Not specified (activity monitored before and after 3 months of SET).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 12-week physical activity counseling program on increasing walking and overall physical activity levels in COPD patients across different care settings.
results_summary: The counseling program significantly increased daily steps and physical activity after 3 months, particularly in outpatient and pulmonary rehabilitation subgroups. Long-term benefits (15 months) were observed only in sedentary patients, while exercise capacity and quality of life improvements were limited to the short term in the outpatient subgroup.
population_specificity: COPD patients (102 males, median age 62) from primary care, secondary care, and pulmonary rehabilitation settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a home-based walking exercise program in managing anxiety, depression, and cancer-related symptoms in lung cancer survivors.
results_summary: The walking-exercise group showed significant improvements in anxiety and depression levels compared to the usual-care group, with statistically significant results at the third and sixth months. The program was deemed feasible and effective for lung cancer rehabilitation.
population_specificity: 116 patients with lung cancer from a medical center in northern Taiwan.
effective_dosage: 40 minutes per day, 3 days per week (moderate-intensity walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare pain levels, mobility, and quality of life between patients who underwent revision total knee arthroplasty (TKA) versus primary TKA.
results_summary: Patients after revision TKA reported higher pain intensity, reduced walking distance, increased use of walking aids, and poorer quality of life compared to those after primary TKA. No significant improvement in walking distance was observed before versus after revision TKA.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis who underwent either revision or primary total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining individualized respiratory muscle training with conventional physical therapy could improve pulmonary function and exercise capacity in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pulmonary function (FVC, FEV1, PEF) and exercise capacity (6MWT, SBMBDS scores) in the group receiving respiratory muscle training compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (n=20, divided into exercise and control groups).
effective_dosage: Respiratory muscle training for 20 min per session, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of triple versus double nonopioid perioperative analgesic regimens in reducing movement-evoked pain and improving functional recovery (including walking) after abdominal hysterectomy.
results_summary: The study found no substantial benefits of adding a third nonopioid analgesic to double-drug regimens. However, exploratory analyses showed consistent negative correlations between pain and functional outcomes like walking (measured via TUG), suggesting pain interference with mobility.
population_specificity: Adult women (>18 years) of ASA status 1-2 undergoing abdominal hysterectomy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study treatments administered for 48 hours, starting 1 hour preoperatively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a community walking training program (CWTP) on walking function and social participation in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The CWTP group showed greater improvement in walking function (measured by 10-m walk test, 6-min walk assessment, and community gait assessment) and social participation compared to the control group, with statistically significant results (P < 0.05).
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (22 participants, 13 male, average age 50.45 years, average post-stroke duration 231.64 days).
effective_dosage: CWTP for 30 min per day, five times a week, in addition to standard rehabilitation (60 min per day, five times a week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intraoperative infiltration with local anesthetic (bupivacaine) versus placebo (saline) affected the development of chronic pain, including pain while walking, after inguinal hernia repair.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in chronic pain (including pain while walking) between the local anesthetic and placebo groups at 3 months postoperatively, with 5.8% in the intervention group and 2.3% in the placebo group reporting pain (VAS ≥ 30). Preoperative pain was identified as an independent risk factor for chronic pain.
population_specificity: Patients with single- or double-sided inguinal hernia undergoing repair.
effective_dosage: 20 mL bupivacaine 0.25% (intervention) or 20 mL saline 0.9% (placebo), administered once intraoperatively.
study_duration: Single intraoperative administration, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine physical activity levels, including walking, during acute inpatient admission after hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: Physical activity levels were extremely low, with patients spending 99% of the day lying or sitting and only 1% standing or walking (16 minutes). Patients took an average of 35.7 steps per day, with no significant difference between weekdays and weekends.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 79.1 years, predominantly women) post-surgical intervention for hip fracture.
study_duration: Duration of acute inpatient admission (not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and outcomes of the Family-Centered Function-Focused-Care (Fam-FFC) intervention in promoting functional recovery, including walking performance, in hospitalized older adults.
results_summary: The intervention group showed better walking performance compared to the control group, though no significant improvements were observed in gait and balance. The study did not report adverse effects related to walking.
population_specificity: Hospitalized older adults aged 65 and older and their family caregivers, predominantly white (89%) with a mean age of 80.8 ± 7.5.
study_duration: Intervention included follow-up after hospitalization, with outcomes measured up to 2 months post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether candesartan improves left ventricular structure, function, and exercise capacity (measured via walking test) in patients with severe aortic stenosis.
results_summary: Candesartan did not significantly improve left ventricular structure, function, or walking distance compared to placebo. Both groups showed a decline in walking distance, reflecting natural disease progression.
population_specificity: 51 patients with severe aortic stenosis (43 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how different walking speed assessment methods influence results and their association with poor health status (low cognitive performance and cardiopulmonary disease) in elderly outpatients.
results_summary: The 10-m walking test yielded higher speeds than the 4-m and 6-min tests, while the 4-m and 6-min tests showed no significant difference. Low cognitive performance and cardiopulmonary disease negatively impacted walking speed, with the 4-m test most sensitive to cognitive decline and the 6-min test most sensitive to cardiopulmonary disease.
population_specificity: 288 community-dwelling elderly (mean age 82.2 ± 7.1 years) referred to a geriatric outpatient clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait speeds obtained from different testing protocols in the same individuals to understand how protocol variations impact recorded gait speed.
results_summary: The study found that starting protocol (standing vs. walking), testing surface (over ground vs. computerized walkway), and walking pace (usual vs. fast) significantly impact recorded gait speed in older adults, with walking starts yielding faster speeds than standing starts, and fast paces yielding faster speeds than usual paces.
population_specificity: 104 community-dwelling older adults who could ambulate household distances independently (mean age = 77.2 ± 6.1).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (gait speed testing protocols, not a dosage-based intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intensive mobility training including body weight-supported treadmill training (BWSTT) provides superior gait, balance, and mobility outcomes compared to overground gait training in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: No significant differences were found between BWSTT and overground gait training groups. Significant improvements were observed in fast walking speed, balance, mobility, and perceived recovery post-intervention, with some effects sustained at 3-month follow-up. Effect sizes were small to moderate.
population_specificity: 43 individuals with chronic stroke (mean age 61.5 years, mean time since stroke 3.3 years).
effective_dosage: 1 hour of gait training, 1 hour of balance activities, and 1 hour of strength, range of motion, and coordination exercises daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of conventional physiotherapy (CP) versus robotic training (RT) combined with CP on gait, balance, functional status, cognitive function, and quality of life in stroke patients.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in most parameters, but the RT group demonstrated better improvements in functional independence (FIM), cognitive function (MMSE), and quality of life (SF-36 subparts) compared to CP alone. The RT group also showed superior outcomes in lower extremity recovery (BRS).
population_specificity: Patients with subacute and chronic stroke (up to 1 year post-stroke).
effective_dosage: RT group: Lokomat training 2 times per week + CP 3 times per week; CP group: CP 5 times per week (minimum 30 sessions total for both groups).
study_duration: At least 30 sessions (duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of two exercise programs (lumbopelvic motor control vs. combined lumbopelvic motor control and hip strengthening) in reducing pain and disability for individuals with non-specific low back pain.
results_summary: Both exercise programs showed clinically meaningful reductions in pain, with no significant difference between the two groups. The addition of hip strengthening exercises did not improve clinical outcomes for pain reduction.
population_specificity: Individuals with non-specific low back pain recruited from community-based general medical practices.
effective_dosage: 6 rehabilitation sessions including real-time ultrasound training, plus a home-based exercise program manual and log book.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether installing bicycle boulevards increased physical activity (including walking) and active transportation among adults with children.
results_summary: The study found no significant correlation between living near newly installed bicycle boulevards and increases in walking (>20 min) or other physical activity measures. Significant covariates included rain, gender, proximity to downtown, and attitudes toward walking and bicycling.
population_specificity: Adults with children (n=353) in Portland, OR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of inhaled glutathione (GSH) on lung function and exercise capacity in cystic fibrosis (CF) patients.
results_summary: Inhaled GSH did not meet the primary outcome of 15% improvement in FEV1%, but it showed a statistically significant increase in FEV1 in patients with moderate lung disease at 3, 6, and 9 months. GSH also improved the 6-minute walking test in pediatric patients and was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Adult and pediatric patients with cystic fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of surgical treatments for femoral hip periprosthetic fractures, focusing on recovery of walking ability and mortality rates.
results_summary: The study found that 73.8% of patients recovered walking ability after surgery, with complete healing and prosthesis stability in 87.3% of cases. Mortality rates were low (1.6% at 3 months, 3.3% at 12 months), but higher when surgery was delayed beyond 5 days.
population_specificity: 61 patients undergoing surgery for femoral hip periprosthetic fractures.

study_goal: The researchers investigated whether intracoronary transplantation of CD34(+) cells improves myocardial perfusion and functional outcomes (including 6-minute walking distance) in patients with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in myocardial perfusion, left ventricular ejection fraction, and 6-minute walking distance (354 ± 71 m to 404 ± 91 m) at 6-month follow-up after CD34(+) cell transplantation. Patients with less severe baseline perfusion defects showed better response to therapy.
population_specificity: 21 patients with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (LVEF <40%, NYHA class III; 81% male, mean age 53 ± 9 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (CD34(+) cells collected via apheresis and injected into coronary arteries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent findings on the mechanics of walking and its relationship to osteoarthritis (OA), focusing on mechanobiology, ambulatory mechanics, biomechanical interventions, and mechanical risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that biomechanical interventions like shoe insoles and knee braces had variable effects on knee joint moments during walking, while lateral wedge insoles did not significantly reduce pain. Diet with or without exercise reduced knee joint load indicators, but exercise alone did not show similar effects with the measures used.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk for osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 5-day mind-body exercise program, including walking and Feldenkrais-based training, on quality of life, balance, mobility, and gait in community-dwelling women.
results_summary: The MBE group showed statistically significant improvements in mobility, stride length, single limb support time, balance confidence, and quality of life, while the control group exhibited no changes.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling women aged 40-80 years.
effective_dosage: Multiple daily sessions of Feldenkrais-based sensorimotor movement training and walking (exact frequency/duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of physical and geriatric rehabilitation on institutionalization, mortality, and functional outcomes (including walking ability) after hip fracture.
results_summary: Physical rehabilitation reduced mortality compared to geriatric rehabilitation and control groups at 4 and 12 months. Both physical and geriatric rehabilitation improved independent living at 4 months, particularly for femoral neck fracture patients, but no significant impact on walking ability or ADL functions was observed.
population_specificity: Independently living patients (n=538) with non-pathological hip fracture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and pilot an e-health intervention to increase physical activity (walking) and reduce fat mass in overweight or obese individuals with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The intervention led to significant improvements in fat mass, trunk fat mass, symptom severity, energy intake, maximum continuous activity, and mental health. Non-significant improvements were observed for waist circumference, pain, disability, and obesity biomarkers, with 70% losing weight, 50% increasing walking capacity, and 60% improving quality of life.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese individuals (n=10, mean age 67.5±6.7 years, 60% women) with clinically confirmed lumbar spinal stenosis.
effective_dosage: Personalized step goals via pedometer; no specific walking dosage mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if subsensory vibratory noise applied to the soles of the feet via piezoelectric insoles could improve balance, gait, and reduce fall-related measures in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that vibratory insoles significantly improved performance on the TUG test, reduced postural sway, and decreased gait variability at 70% and 85% of the sensory threshold, with effects lasting throughout the day.
population_specificity: Healthy community-dwelling elderly volunteers aged 65-90 years.
effective_dosage: 70% and 85% of the sensory threshold, set once daily.
study_duration: 3 days (crossover study with different stimulation levels each day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of supervised exercise training (SET) after percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) compared with PTA alone on physical function, limb hemodynamics, and health-related quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in physical function and limb hemodynamics for both groups, with greater improvements in the intervention group (SET) compared to the control group (PTA alone). The intervention group showed median improvements of 66m in the 6-minute walk test and 251m in maximum walking distance, while the control group improved by 45m and 93m, respectively.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication who underwent PTA.
effective_dosage: Two sessions of hospital-based SET and one home-based exercise session per week.

study_goal: To determine if FES-assisted active cycling is more effective than active cycling without FES for improving walking and balance in stroke patients with severe hemiparesis.
results_summary: FES-assisted cycling significantly improved walking ability (FAC) and balance (POMA) compared to active cycling alone, with greater median improvements in the FES group. Both groups showed significant improvements in leg motricity, but no differences were observed in spasticity (modified Ashworth scale).
population_specificity: Patients with severe hemiparesis due to stroke (N=40).
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of active leg cycling with or without FES, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and synthesize the biomechanical effects of valgus knee bracing on patients with medial knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: Valgus knee braces were found to decrease medial knee compressive force, improve load distribution, reduce co-contraction ratios, and increase medial joint space during gait. Meta-analysis showed a significant reduction in the external knee adduction moment (KAM) with moderate-to-high effect sizes.
population_specificity: Patients with medial knee osteoarthritis (OA).
study_duration: Duration varied; meta-regression suggested longer brace use was associated with smaller treatment effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether a task-oriented motor learning intervention improves motor control of gait in older adults with subclinical walking difficulty compared to a standard exercise program.
results_summary: The motor learning group showed greater improvements in gait variability and smoothness of walking compared to the standard exercise group, particularly in double-support time variability and smoothness in anteroposterior and vertical directions under various conditions.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥65 years with gait speed >1.0m/s and impaired motor skill (figure-of-8 walk time >8s).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the complexities and gaps in the management of paediatric pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), including diagnostic challenges and the lack of evidence for therapeutic approaches.
results_summary: The abstract notes that treatments for paediatric PAH lack sufficient examination, particularly regarding toxicities, dosing, and clinical trial endpoints, and emphasizes the need for optimal endpoints to evaluate efficacy and safety in this population.
population_specificity: Paediatric patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of three artificial neural networks (ANNs) in classifying recurrent fallers versus non-recurrent fallers among older adults using clinical characteristics related to fall risk.
results_summary: The study found that the NEAT ANN, using 15 clinical characteristics, was the most efficient for identifying recurrent fallers, with high sensitivity (80.42%), specificity (92.54%), and accuracy (88.39%). The other ANNs (MLP and modified MLP) performed less effectively.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 65 and older (n=3289).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week exercise program, including resistance training and a pedometer-based walking program, could reduce PTSD symptoms and improve secondary outcomes like depression, waist circumference, and sleep quality compared to usual care alone.
results_summary: The study found that the exercise intervention significantly reduced PTSD symptoms, depressive symptoms, waist circumference, and sedentary time while improving sleep quality compared to usual care. The intervention group showed clinically meaningful improvements across multiple outcomes.
population_specificity: 81 participants (84% male, mean age 47.8) with a DSM-IV-TR diagnosis of primary PTSD, recruited from an in-patient program at a private hospital.
effective_dosage: Three 30-minute resistance-training sessions per week plus a pedometer-based walking program (specific step count not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate associations between worksite neighborhood context and changes in obesogenic behaviors, including walking, among adult employees.
results_summary: Higher worksite neighborhood socioeconomic status (NSES) was associated with increased walking, and higher residential density around worksites was linked to more walking and healthier dietary habits, independent of NSES. Residential density partially mediated the relationship between worksite NSES and these behaviors.
population_specificity: Adult employees participating in a worksite randomized trial to prevent weight gain.
study_duration: Data collected at baseline (2005-2007) and follow-up (2007-2009).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining standing, electrical stimulation, and splinting was more effective than standing alone for managing ankle contractures in severe brain injury patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in passive ankle dorsiflexion between the experimental and control groups, with a small, temporary reduction in spasticity favoring the experimental group. No other secondary outcomes showed meaningful differences.
population_specificity: Adults with severe traumatic brain injury and ankle plantarflexion contractures.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention details: tilt table standing, electrical stimulation, and ankle splinting for experimental group; tilt table standing alone for control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes of a modified Brostrom procedure using the suture bridge technique for treating chronic lateral ankle instability in high-demand athletes.
results_summary: The procedure significantly improved ankle stability and function, with 91.7% of patients achieving satisfactory results. Patients returned to various activities, including walking on uneven ground, at an average of 10.6 weeks post-surgery.
population_specificity: High-demand athletes under 30 years old with chronic lateral ankle instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess factors influencing functional recovery, particularly walking ability, in older adults after hip surgery and determine the role of cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study found that 58% of patients regained pre-fracture walking ability, with higher recovery rates in those without cognitive impairment (73.7%) compared to those with mild (50%) or severe impairment (5%). Previous walking ability and complications like pressure ulcers or delirium were stronger predictors of recovery than cognitive impairment.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥65 years) admitted for rehabilitation after a hip operation.
study_duration: Measured at basal, admission, and discharge (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of autologous bone marrow-derived ALDH(br) cells in improving peak walking time and leg collateral arterial anatomy in patients with intermittent claudication due to PAD.
results_summary: The study will evaluate changes in peak walking time, leg collateral arterial anatomy, calf muscle blood flow, and tissue perfusion at 6 months compared to baseline, using advanced MRI end points to quantify biologic and mechanistic effects of cell therapy.
population_specificity: 80 patients with symptom-limiting intermittent claudication due to significant stenosis or occlusion of infrainguinal arteries and a resting ankle-brachial index <0.90.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a guided imagery and relaxation exercise DVD intervention could improve postoperative pain management, including walking, in adolescents undergoing spinal fusion surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group experienced a 2-point improvement in walking on a 10-point scale compared to the control group, with statistical significance (p = .003). The intervention was more effective than standard care alone for postoperative pain.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults (ages 11-20 years) undergoing spinal fusion surgery at a tertiary care hospital in Montreal, Canada.
effective_dosage: The intervention involved practicing guided imagery/relaxation exercises at least three times a week at home.
study_duration: The intervention was administered from preoperative screening to 1-month postoperative follow-up.
